paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine sensitize non-responsive tumors to anti-PD-L1 therapy by creating an interferon-rich inflammatory state?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Combination Efficacy Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Mice pooled from repeat preclinical experiments, treated with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combination therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse Preclinical Control Cohorts
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Mice used for vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle control treatments to establish baseline and monotherapy activity.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human Retrospective Metastatic Cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic cancer patients receiving ICI treatment, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human Vaccinated Subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of metastatic ICI-treated patients who had received the SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine prior to ICI initiation for survival comparison.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
